attributes.title: Mental health and psychosocial support strategies in highly contagious emerging disease outbreaks of substantial public concern: a systematic scoping review

summary.value:
Systematic scoping review to identify and summarise the available literature of interventions that aim to promote mental health and psychosocial support in people who are or were affected by highly contagious emerging disease outbreaks of substantial public concern such as SARS, MERS, COVID-19, or Ebola, or are expected to be. 
We aim to systematically examine relevant research in the field in order to inform researchers, policy makers and other deciders in clinical and public settings about available approaches and crucial intervention elements. We will also suggest considerations for the future planning of intervention studies during pandemics as well as to develop pandemic preparedness plans.

This scoping review was performed in view of the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic in order to provide an initial basis for the decisions of researchers and policy makers concerning mental health and psychosocial support strategies. Therefore, this protocol was written in parallel/after performing the review.

registration_responses.summary:
Systematic scoping review to identify and summarise the available literature of interventions that aim to promote mental health and psychosocial support in people who are or were affected by highly contagious emerging disease outbreaks of substantial public concern such as SARS, MERS, COVID-19, or Ebola, or are expected to be. 
We aim to systematically examine relevant research in the field in order to inform researchers, policy makers and other deciders in clinical and public settings about available approaches and crucial intervention elements. We will also suggest considerations for the future planning of intervention studies during pandemics as well as to develop pandemic preparedness plans.

This scoping review was performed in view of the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic in order to provide an initial basis for the decisions of researchers and policy makers concerning mental health and psychosocial support strategies. Therefore, this protocol was written in parallel/after performing the review.

attributes.title: Gender Inequality
attributes.description: This study tests if reading news items that report on sexism can instill feelings of social exclusion among women, and result in decreased expectations of success and demotivation in the job market.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

other.value:
Some exploratory analyses may be conducted, to test if the need threats mediate the relation between conditions and feelings of demotivation. We may also test if expectations of chances in the job market mediate the relation between conditions and experienced demotivation.

In the results, we describe p-values equal or below 0.05 to be significant, between 0.05 and 0.10 to be marginally significant, and above 0.10 to be non-significant.

sample.value: Data will be collected among 250 British female participants, with a university Bachelor degree or higher, between 18 and 50 years old.

analyses.value:
For H1, we test with an independent t-test if participants in the confirmation of sexism condition experience increased exclusion compared to participants in the control condition.

For H2, we test with an independent t-test if participants in the confirmation of sexism condition experience increased need threats compared to participants in the control condition.

For H3, we test with an independent t-test if participants in the confirmation of sexism condition experience increased negative feelings compared to participants in the control condition.

For H4, we test with an independent t-test if participants in the confirmation of sexism condition experience decreased expectations of success in the job market, compared to participants in the control condition.

For H5, we test with an independent t-test if participants in the confirmation of sexism condition experience increased demotivation to achieve a desirable position in the job market, compared to participants in the control condition.

For H6, we test with a moderation analyses with 10.000 bootstrap resamples whether or not prior experience with being treated in a sexist manner moderates the effect of the conditions on exclusion, negative feelings, need threats, expectations, and demotivation. More (vs. less) frequent experiences with being treated in a sexist manner may either reduce or increase the effect of confirmations of sexism on these factors.

outliers.value:
Participants will be excluded from the analyses if:

- They do not indicate they identify as female.
- Their answer to the open question in the confirmation of sexism conditions shows that they have not read the articles. 
- They do not complete the full survey.

dependent.value:
All items are answered on a 7-point scale with 1 = Totally disagree, 7 = Totally agree, unless noted otherwise.

Exclusion: "I am being excluded by society”, and "I am being rejected by society".
Need threats: "I do not really feel like I belong in society", and, reverse-scored "I feel accepted by society" (belonging). Reverse-scored: "I experience personal control over where I end up in society", and "I have the feeling that others decide for me where I end up in society" (control). Reverse-scored: "My position in society makes me feel good about myself". and, "My position in society has a negative effect on my self-esteem" (self-esteem). "I feel invisible in society" and, reverse-scored, "My position in society gives me the feelings that my life is meaningful". All items are collapsed into one measure of need threats, if reliability allows.

Negative feelings: “Given my position in society I feel..”, “sad”, “angry”, “hurt”, “happy”, “elated”, “cheerful”, last three items reverse coded (adapted from Van Beest & Williams, 2006). All items are collapsed into one measure of 'feelings' if reliability allows.

Participants are asked to "consider for a moment the highest position that you would like to hold in your working life. You may aspire to move up in the company you work in, or dream to hold some high-regarded position in society. Below, please indicate the highest possible position that you would like to achieve."

Expectations of success: "Think back on the highest possible position that you mentioned you would like to achieve, and indicate below to what extent you agree with the statements."
"I think discrimination will not stand in my way of achieving this position.", and, reverse-coded, "Personally, I think that compared to an equally skilled male candidate, my chances of achieving this position are much smaller.". Both items are collapsed into one measure of expectation of success, if reliability allows.

Demotivation: “How do you feel about trying to acquire this position?" answer options 1 = Demotivated, 7 = Motivated, and 1 = Discouraged, 7 = Encouraged. Both items are reversed and collapsed into one measure of demotivation, if reliability allows.

Ambition: To get a sense of how ambitious participants in our sample are, one exploratory control question is asked: "In general, as how ambitious do you see yourself with regards to your career?", 1 = Very unambitious, 7 = Very ambitious.

Sexist encounters are measured with 2 questions: "How often have you personally encountered a situation in which you were treated in a sexist way?" and "How often have you personally encountered a situation in which you felt discriminated against because of your gender?", 1 = Never, 7 = Very often.

conditions.value:
Participants are assigned to one of two conditions: the confirmation of sexism vs. the control condition.

In the confirmation of sexism condition, participants read the opening paragraphs of six news articles that report on how women are discriminated against in society.
In the control condition participants are asked to answer the questions without reading these articles.

hypothesis.value:
To raise awareness of sexism, in news media there is a lot of attention for sexism as the root of gender inequality. Such coverage confirms the occurrence of sexism. The current research tests if confirming sexism may also have negative effects, because for women it may strengthen the idea that being discriminated against for them is the norm. In this study, we test whether exposure to a series of news articles about sexism causes feelings of exclusion from society, lower need fulfilment, more negative feelings, and lower perceived chances of success and increased demotivation in the job market.

H1: We predict that after exposure to confirmations of sexism, women’s feelings of exclusion are higher than in the control condition.
H2: We predict that after exposure to confirmations of sexism, women’s needs are more threatened than in the control condition.
H3: We predict that after exposure to confirmations of sexism, women’s feelings are more negative than in the control condition.
H4: We predict that after exposure to confirmations of sexism, women’s expectations of their chances to find a desirable job are lower than in the control condition.
H5: We predict that after exposure to confirmations of sexism, women’s experiences of demotivation towards acquiring a desirable job position are higher than in the control condition.
H6: As an explorative hypothesis, we test whether women's first hand experiences with being treated in a sexist manner moderate the effect of exposure to confirmations of sexism (vs. the control condition) on exclusion, negative feelings, need threats, and expectations and demotivation in the job market.

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.
registration_responses.name: Gender inequality - Experimental study Prolific
registration_responses.other:
Some exploratory analyses may be conducted, to test if the need threats mediate the relation between conditions and feelings of demotivation. We may also test if expectations of chances in the job market mediate the relation between conditions and experienced demotivation.

In the results, we describe p-values equal or below 0.05 to be significant, between 0.05 and 0.10 to be marginally significant, and above 0.10 to be non-significant.

For H1, we test with an independent t-test if participants in the confirmation of sexism condition experience increased exclusion compared to participants in the control condition.

For H2, we test with an independent t-test if participants in the confirmation of sexism condition experience increased need threats compared to participants in the control condition.

For H3, we test with an independent t-test if participants in the confirmation of sexism condition experience increased negative feelings compared to participants in the control condition.

For H4, we test with an independent t-test if participants in the confirmation of sexism condition experience decreased expectations of success in the job market, compared to participants in the control condition.

For H5, we test with an independent t-test if participants in the confirmation of sexism condition experience increased demotivation to achieve a desirable position in the job market, compared to participants in the control condition.

For H6, we test with a moderation analyses with 10.000 bootstrap resamples whether or not prior experience with being treated in a sexist manner moderates the effect of the conditions on exclusion, negative feelings, need threats, expectations, and demotivation. More (vs. less) frequent experiences with being treated in a sexist manner may either reduce or increase the effect of confirmations of sexism on these factors.

- They do not indicate they identify as female.
- Their answer to the open question in the confirmation of sexism conditions shows that they have not read the articles. 
- They do not complete the full survey.

attributes.title: Therapeutic Relationships in Child and Adolescent Mental Health Services: Feasibility and acceptability of a staff intervention for inpatient services
attributes.description:
Therapeutic alliance, or the relationship between professional and service user, has the greatest impact on treatment outcomes in mental health, over and above the specific mode or model of therapy (Duncan et al., 2010; Wampold, 2001). Particularly in child and adolescent mental health services (CAMHS), the alliance between the child or family and staff on inpatient units is the key predictor of positive outcomes from admission (Green et al., 2007; Karver 2006; Shirk and Karver, 2003). Working in partnership with family members is essential to inpatient provision, although often complicated by the family’s own history with services and complex family dynamics (Gross & Goldin, 2008).
Young people identify that relationships with staff can ease the experience of the admission (Street & Svanberg, 2003a; 2003b) and they especially appreciate professionalism and expertise in the context of reciprocal engagement; making a ‘human connection’ (Sischy, 2006). The relationship between staff members and young people can contribute towards a therapeutic milieu that aids recovery even when young people struggle to access direct interventions, i.e. one-to-one therapy (Sergeant, 2009). Despite its importance, poor alliance is the main factor for ending therapeutic treatment (Garcia and Weisz, 2002), with various challenges to its development. Staff members suffer high levels of burnout (Johnson et al, 2012) and there are difficulties maintaining a skilled and sufficient workforce (Nixon, 2006). It is therefore essential that front-line professionals are well supported in managing these relationships (Ellis, 2016) in a way that is acceptable and feasible to them and the service. 
When working with young people especially, there is a need to navigate issues of power and control (Colton & Pistrang, 2004) and manage the ‘push and pull’ of working with adolescents who have disrupted ways of relating to people due to their early relationships (Cross, 2016). The alliance is difficult for young people who have been maltreated (Eltz and Shirk, 1995) and the developmental trend toward increasing autonomy from adults can represent an additional obstacle (DiGiuseppe, Linscott, & Jilton, 1996). 
Nursing staff are best placed to provide caring relationships, but interactions are often not therapeutic or guided by the psychological theory of relationships (Cameron, Kapur & Campbell, 2005). There has been some progress in the adult service research field, with indications that clinical supervision can protect against staff burnout (Edwards et al., 2006) and psychologically-informed case discussions can enhance positive feelings towards service users and reduce staff self-blame (Berry et al., 2009). Team-based training to develop staff skills using psychological models can even improve service user engagement (Caruso et al., 2013). However, there is currently no well-evidenced intervention to support nursing staff to develop and manage the most important part of their work (Hartley, Raphael, Lovell, Berry, 2019). Moreover, prior preliminary work in the adult field has not taken into account the specific challenges of the CAMHS context outlined above, does not involve relationships with the wider family (‘carers’) and has not been developed with stakeholder involvement at its heart.

We therefore have created a theoretically-driven, tailored and stakeholder-informed intervention that will support the development and maintenance of helpful therapeutic relationships between nursing staff, young people and carers within inpatient CAMHS. the purpose of the current study will be to evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of this staff-based intervention.

q2.value:
The aims of the current study are to:
1.	Assess the feasibility of the intervention
2.	Assess the acceptability of the intervention
3.	Assess the feasibility of the research design
The secondary aims are to:
4.	Explore appropriate outcome measures for use in a pilot trial 

We hypothesise that the intervention will be acceptable and feasible to deliver to nursing staff in an inpatient child and adolescent mental health service.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We will employ a mixed-methods design, combining in-depth qualitative data with repeated measurement of outcomes in a non-randomised, time series design with the ward as a single case. We will also employ pre-post measures before and after each element of the intervention.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Setting
The setting is a general adolescent inpatient child and adolescent mental health ward.  

Participants
The main target for the intervention is nursing staff. Staff will be eligible to consent if they are a qualified nurse or non-qualified nursing assistant
Young people and family members/ carers will also be recruited to provide feedback and outcomes in relation to the intervention. Young people (aged 13-18) will be eligible if they are current inpatients on the ward and are deemed competent (13-16) or capacitous (16-18) to provide informed consent. Carers (aged 18 or over) will be eligible if they currently have a young person admitted to the ward. All members of staff and all young people and carers on the ward at the start of the study will be invited to take part. New staff will be offered participation and consented following completion of their induction into the ward. New young people and carers will be offered participation and consented as soon as possible following admission.

q11.value: Predicted sample size is 40 (including staff, young people and carers).

q12.value: A power analysis is not applicable. Sample size prediction is based on estimate clinical staff team size and admission rates.

q13.value: Data collection will continue throughout the trial period (baseline, intervention and follow up over 20 weeks).

question.value: There are no separate treatment arms. The study will follow a time series design, whereby data is collected over a baseline period (4 weeks), intervention (12 weeks), and follow up (4 weeks)
Please see attached file for full details of outcome measures.

Primary outcomes are Feasibility (% of intervention elements delivered and attended), acceptability (staff satisfaction and experiences). Primary outcomes will consist of reported percentages, visual plotting of data and descriptive statistics. Qualitative analysis will be done in line with thematic analysis framework (Braun and Clarke, 2019). Effect sizes for secondary outcomes will be reported.

q21.value: Where 10% or less of the data is missing from an individual measure and time-point, the missing data will be imputed with the mean value.

1.	Assess the feasibility of the intervention
2.	Assess the acceptability of the intervention
3.	Assess the feasibility of the research design
The secondary aims are to:
4.	Explore appropriate outcome measures for use in a pilot trial 

We hypothesise that the intervention will be acceptable and feasible to deliver to nursing staff in an inpatient child and adolescent mental health service.

attributes.title: Norm attribution
attributes.description: This study will investigate whether social norms have a differential effect on conformity depending on whether the norm is intrinsically vs extrinsically attributed and whether type of attribution will affect the generality of the social norm.

q2.value:
1. The intrinsically attributed norm condition and the extrinsically attributed norm condition will increase conformity to a specific norm, compared to the control condition.
2. The intrinsically attributed norm condition will increase conformity to a specific norm, compared to the extrinsically attributed norm condition.
3. The intrinsically attributed norm condition will increase conformity to a generalized norm, compared to the extrinsically attributed norm condition.
4. The intrinsically attributed norm condition will increase conformity to a generalized norm, compared to the control condition.
5. The intrinsically attributed norm condition will increase perception of other people’s conformity to a generalized norm, compared to the extrinsically attributed norm condition.
6. The intrinsically attributed norm condition will increase perception of other people’s conformity to a generalized norm, compared to the control condition.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Between subjects design with one factor (type of social norm) and three conditions (control vs intrinsically attributed social norm vs extrinsically attributed social norm).

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will sample subjects from Amazons MTurk. Only participants currently residing within the U.S, has an HIT approval rate of over 90%, has at least 100 HITs approved and is over 18 years of age will be included in the study.

q12.value: An a priori power calculation for binary logistic regression indicated that 644 was a sufficient sample size to detect an effect size of OR = 1.72 with greater than .80 power (α = .05). A pilot study indicated that approximately 14% of participants may not be attentive to the manipulation, and our final sample will therefore be 735 participants to account for possible exclusions.

question.value:
Intrinsically attributed social norm will be manipulated by stating that “In this survey, we are interested in how Mturkers view eco-labeled chocolate bars and their product preferences. In the communal shopping cart below  you can see the total product choice of Mturkers taking our HITs.
 
Mturkers taking our HITs have stated that the reasons for choosing the eco-labeled chocolate bar are because they feel a sense of pleasure when improving environmental quality and because they like the way they feel when doing things for the environment.”
 
The extrinsically attributed social norm will be manipulated by stating that “In this survey, we are interested in how Mturkers view eco-labeled chocolate bars and their product preferences. In the communal shopping cart below  you can see the total product choice of Mturkers taking our HITs.
 
Mturkers taking our HITs have stated that the reasons for choosing the eco-labeled chocolate bar are because of the recognition they get from others when doing things for the environment and because they want to avoid criticism.”

In both norm conditions participants will view the same communal shopping cart manipulating the social norm for eco-labeled chocolate bars.

The control condition will not receive information about the social norm in favor of the eco-labeled chocolate bar nor Mturkers motivation for choosing the eco-labeled chocolate bar.

Primary DV: The primary dependent variable is conformity to the social norm, and will be measured as a binary choice between the eco-labeled chocolate bar and the regular chocolate bar. Participants will be asked to drag their preferred product choice to the shopping cart.
Secondary DVs: To gauge the generalizability of the social norm, participants will then be presented with an energy star-labeled light bulb and a regular light bulb and asked to drag the product they think other Mturkers taking the HIT would be more likely to buy to the cart (perception of others choice). They will also be asked to drag the lightbulb they themselves would be more likely to buy to the cart (own choice without normative information). 
Attention check: Participants will then answer a general attention check: “What cocoa percentage did both of the chocolate bars have?” with response options: 30%, 70% . 
Manipulation check: As a manipulation check of the perceived extrinsic and intrinsic motivation of others, participants will indicate how strongly they agree with eight statements (ranging from 1 – strongly disagree to 7 – strongly agree). 
“If Mturkers taking our HITs were to choose the eco-labeled chocolate bar, what do you think their reason for doing so would be?”
1.	Because they want to avoid criticism
2.	Because of the recognition they get from others
3.	Because they feel a sense of pleasure when improving environmental quality
4.	Because they like the way it makes them feel
5.	Because they want to avoid upsetting others
6.	Because their friends insist on it
7.	Because of the pleasure they feel when mastering new ways of helping the environment
8.	Because of the pleasure they feel when contributing to the environment

Lastly, participants will indicate their age and gender.

To analyze our hypotheses we will conduct four binary logistic regressions with experimental condition as the sole IV. 
To test H1, we will perform a binary logistic regression with the control condition as reference category and choice of chocolate bar as dependent variable.
To test H2, we will perform a binary logistic regression with intrinsic social norm as reference category and choice of chocolate bar as dependent variable.
To test H3 and H4, we will perform a binary logistic regression with intrinsic social norm as reference category and choice of lightbulb as dependent variable. 
To test H5 and H6, we will perform a binary logistic regression with intrinsic social norm as reference category and others perceived choice of lightbulb as dependent variable.

q19.value: We will use p-values to make inferences, with α = .05 as our cut-off criteria.

q20.value: All participants who fail the general attention check will be excluded from data analysis.

registration_responses.q2:
1. The intrinsically attributed norm condition and the extrinsically attributed norm condition will increase conformity to a specific norm, compared to the control condition.
2. The intrinsically attributed norm condition will increase conformity to a specific norm, compared to the extrinsically attributed norm condition.
3. The intrinsically attributed norm condition will increase conformity to a generalized norm, compared to the extrinsically attributed norm condition.
4. The intrinsically attributed norm condition will increase conformity to a generalized norm, compared to the control condition.
5. The intrinsically attributed norm condition will increase perception of other people’s conformity to a generalized norm, compared to the extrinsically attributed norm condition.
6. The intrinsically attributed norm condition will increase perception of other people’s conformity to a generalized norm, compared to the control condition.

registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q12: An a priori power calculation for binary logistic regression indicated that 644 was a sufficient sample size to detect an effect size of OR = 1.72 with greater than .80 power (α = .05). A pilot study indicated that approximately 14% of participants may not be attentive to the manipulation, and our final sample will therefore be 735 participants to account for possible exclusions.
registration_responses.q19: We will use p-values to make inferences, with α = .05 as our cut-off criteria.
registration_responses.q20: All participants who fail the general attention check will be excluded from data analysis.
registration_responses.q6.question: Between subjects design with one factor (type of social norm) and three conditions (control vs intrinsically attributed social norm vs extrinsically attributed social norm).
registration_responses.q10.question: We will sample subjects from Amazons MTurk. Only participants currently residing within the U.S, has an HIT approval rate of over 90%, has at least 100 HITs approved and is over 18 years of age will be included in the study.
registration_responses.q14.question:
Intrinsically attributed social norm will be manipulated by stating that “In this survey, we are interested in how Mturkers view eco-labeled chocolate bars and their product preferences. In the communal shopping cart below  you can see the total product choice of Mturkers taking our HITs.
 
Mturkers taking our HITs have stated that the reasons for choosing the eco-labeled chocolate bar are because they feel a sense of pleasure when improving environmental quality and because they like the way they feel when doing things for the environment.”
 
The extrinsically attributed social norm will be manipulated by stating that “In this survey, we are interested in how Mturkers view eco-labeled chocolate bars and their product preferences. In the communal shopping cart below  you can see the total product choice of Mturkers taking our HITs.
 
Mturkers taking our HITs have stated that the reasons for choosing the eco-labeled chocolate bar are because of the recognition they get from others when doing things for the environment and because they want to avoid criticism.”

In both norm conditions participants will view the same communal shopping cart manipulating the social norm for eco-labeled chocolate bars.

The control condition will not receive information about the social norm in favor of the eco-labeled chocolate bar nor Mturkers motivation for choosing the eco-labeled chocolate bar.
registration_responses.q15.question:
Primary DV: The primary dependent variable is conformity to the social norm, and will be measured as a binary choice between the eco-labeled chocolate bar and the regular chocolate bar. Participants will be asked to drag their preferred product choice to the shopping cart.
Secondary DVs: To gauge the generalizability of the social norm, participants will then be presented with an energy star-labeled light bulb and a regular light bulb and asked to drag the product they think other Mturkers taking the HIT would be more likely to buy to the cart (perception of others choice). They will also be asked to drag the lightbulb they themselves would be more likely to buy to the cart (own choice without normative information). 
Attention check: Participants will then answer a general attention check: “What cocoa percentage did both of the chocolate bars have?” with response options: 30%, 70% . 
Manipulation check: As a manipulation check of the perceived extrinsic and intrinsic motivation of others, participants will indicate how strongly they agree with eight statements (ranging from 1 – strongly disagree to 7 – strongly agree). 
“If Mturkers taking our HITs were to choose the eco-labeled chocolate bar, what do you think their reason for doing so would be?”
1.	Because they want to avoid criticism
2.	Because of the recognition they get from others
3.	Because they feel a sense of pleasure when improving environmental quality
4.	Because they like the way it makes them feel
5.	Because they want to avoid upsetting others
6.	Because their friends insist on it
7.	Because of the pleasure they feel when mastering new ways of helping the environment
8.	Because of the pleasure they feel when contributing to the environment

Lastly, participants will indicate their age and gender.
registration_responses.q17.question:
To analyze our hypotheses we will conduct four binary logistic regressions with experimental condition as the sole IV. 
To test H1, we will perform a binary logistic regression with the control condition as reference category and choice of chocolate bar as dependent variable.
To test H2, we will perform a binary logistic regression with intrinsic social norm as reference category and choice of chocolate bar as dependent variable.
To test H3 and H4, we will perform a binary logistic regression with intrinsic social norm as reference category and choice of lightbulb as dependent variable. 
To test H5 and H6, we will perform a binary logistic regression with intrinsic social norm as reference category and others perceived choice of lightbulb as dependent variable.

attributes.title: Human immune response to SARS-CoV-2: What is known? A scoping review
attributes.description: The aim of this work is to review the current publications about the immune response to SARS-CoV-2, what we know at this point, and to summarize the immunology against the virus.

q1.value: Ivon Johanna Rodriguez, Nicolás Lalinde Ruiz, Maria del pilar Montilla, Manuela Llano, Julián Alonso chamucero, Oscar Mauricio Rodríguez, Esteban Alejandro velandia, Laura Camila Martínez, Carlos Alberto Parra López

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This project is a Scoping Review

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q9.value: To identify potentially relevant documents, the following bibliographic databases were searched from December 2019 to March 2020: MEDLINE/PUBMED and EMBASE. The search strategies were drafted by the team member discussion and included MESH, entree and free language terminology. The final search strategy can be found in the Additional file. The final search was exported into Mendeley and duplicates were removed.

question.value: To be included in the review, papers needed to measure or focus on specific dimensions of immunological response in humans when are in contact with SARS-CoV-2. This review included papers in English, human participants, quantitative, qualitative and mixed design, published from December 2019 to 9 of April 2020, qualitative review articles, systematic reviews and case reports. Letters to the editor and expert opinion were excluded, however when these referred articles of interest that were not found in the initial search the new articles were also included.

Selection of Sources of Evidence:  The inclusion criteria of the articles were reviewed in the title and abstract of each article. To increase consistency among the reviewers, teams of four researchers were generated who reviewed the results of the excluded articles and the doubts were resolved by consensus. We resolved disagreement on study selection and data extraction was also resolve by consensus and discussion with other reviews if needed. 
Data Charting Process: A data-charting form was jointly developed by the team to determine which variables to extract.  Each reviewer independently charted the data, and all the group discussed the results and continuously update the data charting form in an iterative process. Data form eligible studies were charted using a tool designed for this study. The tool captured the relevant information on key study characteristics detailed information on all metrics used to estimate/describe the human immune response to SARS-CoV-2. Any disagreements in the final evaluation were resolved through discussion by the team. We extracted data from the main publication and also any referenced published protocols and supplemental materials.  
Data items: We abstract data on article characteristics (e.g, authors, Origen, objectives, purpose), innate and adaptive immune response, cell counts, markers, cytokine storm, T lymphocytes, and B lymphocytes and antibodies. The final version of the charting form was included in the Additional file. 
Synthesis of Results: We grouped the studies by type and items of research. The results were presented in a narrative format, tables, and diagrams.

q20.value: Once we have the database with the results of the search strategy two steps were made to include the papers: first a inclusion/exclusion strategy based on the title and abstract, and then a second review with the full paper.

registration_responses.q1: Ivon Johanna Rodriguez, Nicolás Lalinde Ruiz, Maria del pilar Montilla, Manuela Llano, Julián Alonso chamucero, Oscar Mauricio Rodríguez, Esteban Alejandro velandia, Laura Camila Martínez, Carlos Alberto Parra López
q4: No blinding is involved in this study.

Letters to the editor and expert opinion were excluded, however when these referred articles of interest that were not found in the initial search the new articles were also included.

attributes.title: French handwriting database
attributes.description: database of computerized handwriting samples of BHK texts written by French children from 1st- to 5th-grade, with or without handwriting deficits

summary.value: This project provides a database of kinematic and static features extracted from handwritten texts from 62 dysgraphic and 218 typical children.

registration_responses.summary: This project provides a database of kinematic and static features extracted from handwritten texts from 62 dysgraphic and 218 typical children.

attributes.title: Understanding consumer acceptance of urban-grown food
attributes.description: An online study to investigate consumer choice and willingness to pay for urban grown food, and factors that may influence this.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Understanding consumer acceptance of urban-grown food: an online study to explore the effect of food production information on consumer choice and willingness to pay.

other.value:
Secondary analysis
Correlations will be explored between proximity and engagement with UA, health and ethics-related food choice motivations and participant demographics (age, gender, socioeconomic status).

Exploratory analysis -  we may conduct a mediation analysis to further explore effects between UA, Food choice motivations, and consumer choice outcomes. 

Participants will be UK-based.

We will use Prolific and traditional recruitment methods (posters, flyers, word of mouth, online adverts) to recruit participants.

sample.value:
Participants will be 387 adults. Inclusion criteria are: aged 18 years or over, fluent in English, based in the UK. Exclusion criteria are: aged less than 18 years, not fluent in English, not based in the UK. Sample size was determined by power analysis for a binomial (dichotomous) Poisson Regression for the FCP portion of the survey, plus a 10% allowance for participant attrition. Estimates of effect size were taken from Duckworth et al (in preparation) using a similar design:
Tails: 2 (non-directional)
Exp: 1.15 (enough power to detect a 15% change. NOTE: increase and decreases from 1 are asymmetrical) 
Alpha: .05 (standard)
Beta: 85% (standard-high)
Base rate: 0.5 (In the control vs. control condition, each participant has to make 10 choices, and we expect a roughly 50/50 choice pattern between left and right control products)
Mean exposure: 10 (product pairs presented)
R2 other X: .02 (based on typically small correlations found in psych studies of r = .15)
X distribution: Binomial (not Poisson chosen as we’re dealing with dichotomous IVs)
X parm π: Sample sizes is equal (0.5)
Sample size = 351 = 387 with 10% attrition allowance

analyses.value:
Primary analysis
Forced choice- Poisson regressions will be used to analyse choice data, comparing choice for urban-grown, traditionally grown, and control products. Typical parameters will be set for Poisson and post hoc adjustments will be made based on model fit (or lack thereof), as has been described elsewhere (e.g., Coxe, West, & Aiken, 2009). 
Willingness to pay - WS ANOVA with condition as between subject factor, amount willing to pay as within subject factor.
Secondary analysis
Correlations will be explored between proximity and engagement with UA, health and ethics-related food choice motivations and participant demographics (age, gender, socioeconomic status).

outliers.value: Responses with incomplete (missing data) cases for primary DVs will not be analysed. Responses from participants who fail either or both of the attention checks will be excluded. Data will be inspected for extreme cases and nonsense responding.

dependent.value:
Primary dependent variables will be: 1) FCT – count of number of products selected for each category. 2) WTP Scale data (0-100) gleaned via willingness-to-pay scales for each product in the matched pair. Note that the values of WTP DVs are as a function of percent increase/decrease from the common retail price, and not the raw price. 

Additional DV's are from measures used for exploratory analysis and covariates - Scores on scales E and H of the Food Choice Motivation Questionnaire; Urban Agriculture Proximity and Engagement scale score; NSS-SEC Social Economic Status; age, gender, VAS scores for opinions of urban grown food.

conditions.value:
Participants will be randomly allocated to one of four conditions by the survey software (between subject factor) and they will make choices and payment decisions for the two categories of food (within subject factor). Independent variables will be the type of food presented (urban-grown, traditionally farmed, control), counterbalanced to produce four experimental conditions. The four conditions will be:
-	Urban-grown vs control
-	Traditional grown vs control
-	Control vs control
-	Urban grown vs traditionally grown

hypothesis.value:
Primary aims
To assess consumer acceptance and willingness to pay for urban-grown food. We do not make specific predictions about direction of effects here.

Aim 1: To investigate how many times consumers choose urban-grown food products compared to traditionally -grown food products and control products.
Aim 2: To investigate consumer willingness to pay for urban-grown food products compared to traditionally -grown food products and control products.

Secondary aims
Aim 3: To explore how proximity and engagement with urban agriculture, health and ethics-related food choice motivations and participant demographics (age, gender, socioeconomic status) affect consumer choice and willingness to pay for urban-grown food.

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.
